Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hello ! 
Nice to hear from you again.

>A few questions: Do you have any pi=
ctures or animations from your
>work?  

I've got a huge MS Word document o=
n the project. I'll try to upload it somewhere and share it with the rest o=
f you. 
But no promises! The internet back here is extremely slow :(

>Also=
, what were the final networks like in terms of topology? 

Well, most of t=
he times, if we let the evolution go on for hours, the networks keep gettin=
g more and more complex, although the best fitness and the average fitnesse=
s seemed to reach a certain maximum value after some generations. And an in=
crease in the complexity of architecture didn't do much good to the perform=
ance of the robots, instead it just increased the computation overhead. 

O=
ne of the interesting neural nets that got evolved for flocking with 5-6 ro=
bots, and performed very well with 100+ robots had just the input layer (6 =
neurons), one neuron in the hidden layer, and the output layer(3 neurons). =
Interestingly enough, no recursion was required for this behavior. 

>Final=
ly, like Derek, I also wonder which version of NEAT you used, or
>if you wr=
ote your own?

I used your implementation for single machine. And modified =
it for multiple machines.

>Good luck with your grad school applications.  =
Are you thinking of
>applying in the US?

Thanks :), I'd need loads of it. =

Yes, I will apply to the US. Haven't finalized any universities as yet. 

=
You recommended UCSD, could you guys suggest more places where similar work=
 is going on? 
I know, UT Austin is one :)

Regards,
- Umer
